awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Early Mammalian Embryo Development: Stochastic Modeling and Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
A critical event in mammalian embryo development is construction of embryonic versus extra embryonic structures. Initially, a single cell divides multiple times to generate an aggregate of 10-20 similar cells. Soon after, the progeny of these precursor cells differentiate and self-organize to form other structures. The remarkable feature of this process is its high level of reproducibility despite a number of sources of stochastic variation. In recent years, experimental interrogation has suggested multiple theories for what might be responsible for this process. It is still unclear, however, what drives organization, and in particular, what is responsible for its robustness. This project takes a joint experimental and modeling approach to address this issue. On the modeling side, a novel computational modeling platform will be developed that incorporates known and hypothesized physical and genetic processes to test their influence individually and jointly on development. On the experimental side, imaging and image analysis will be performed on mouse embryos to inform this model and test its predictions. This framework will be initially developed in relation to mouse development and later extended to determine how known differences between early mouse and human cells influence organization, which evidence suggests is less robust in developing human embryos.

This project will shed new light into how mammalian pre-implantation forms from a single cell. The research will also establish new principles for how the interplay between physical and biochemical regulatory processes leads to development of tissues an organisms of exquisite complexity. A multi-scale and stochastic computational framework to study both mouse and human early embryo development will be developed. In addition, this project will develop new training activities involving graduate, undergraduate, and high school students with an emphasis on promoting quantitative thinking and developing modeling and simulation skills. This training will equip students with computational and system-level approaches needed to investigate complex systems. The activities will take advantage of the strengths of the undergraduate and graduate training programs in computational systems biology at the University of California, Irvine and the strong interdisciplinary training programs and ties with minority serving institutions at Vanderbilt University. These programs will be cross-pollinated to promote diversity at all educational levels.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Mammalian development is incredibly robust. Splitting of early-stage embryos, fusion of embryos, and removal of cells from an embryo, all lead to normal development.  One major unaddressed question in biology is how early mammalian embryo robustly create different types of cells from one cell at the start of life.    During this four-year funding period, we have used a systems biology approach integrating modeling and experimentation to investigate this challenging question.   Forty-one journal publications have been resulted from this work. In those publications, we identified critical regulatory circuits and their specific functions in early embryo development, characterized and discovered several general principles for developmental biology. In addition, we developed several multiscale mathematical models and compactional methods that have broader applications in investigating complex biological systems.

One major biological result is on the role of noise in mammalian embryo development. A critical event in mammalian embryo development is construction of an inner cell mass surrounded by a trophoectoderm (a shell of cells that later form extraembryonic structures). We utilize multi?scale, stochastic modeling, and experiments to investigate the design principles responsible for robust establishment of these structures. This investigation makes three predictions, each supported by our quantitative imaging. First, stochasticity in the expression of critical genes promotes cell plasticity and has a critical role in accurately organizing the developing mouse blastocyst. Second, asymmetry in the levels of noise variation (expression fluctuation) of Cdx2 and Oct4 provides a means to gain the benefits of noise? mediated plasticity while ameliorating the potentially detrimental effects of stochasticity. Finally, by controlling the timing and pace of cell fate specification, the embryo temporally modulates plasticity and creates a time window during which each cell can continually read its environment and adjusts its fate. These results suggest noise has a crucial and novel role in maintaining cellular plasticity and organizing the blastocyst (PLoS Comput Biol. 2017, 13(1):e1005320).

One major mathematical result is development of multiscale models that connect physical models with single-cell gene expression data (PLoS Comput Biol. 2021, 17(3) e1008571). We built a multiscale three-dimensional model for mammalian embryo (the very first such model in three dimensions) to recapitulate the observed patterning process from zygote to late blastocyst. By integrating the spatiotemporal information reconstructed from multiple single-cell transcriptomic datasets, the data-informed modeling analysis suggests two major processes critical to the formation of Epi/PE layers: a selective cell-cell adhesion mechanism (via EphA4/EphrinB2) for fate-location coordination and a temporal attenuation mechanism of cell signaling (via Fgf). Spatial imaging data and distinct subsets of single-cell gene expression data are then used to validate the predictions. Together, our study provides a multiscale framework that incorporates single-cell gene expression datasets to analyze gene regulations, cell-cell communications, and physical interactions among cells in complex geometries at single-cell resolution, with direct application to late-stage development of embryogenesis.

We explored available single-cell RNA-seq data to examine primitive endodermal (PrE) cell segregation, that produces extraembryonic structures known as visceral endoderm (VE) and parietal endoderm (PE). Examination of a single-cell cluster representing PrE cells identified three key transcriptional factors, SOX17, GATA6, and FOXA, and BMP signaling in directing the differentiation PrE. We created GATA6 and SOX17 proteins that can be rapidly degraded upon dTAG peptide treatment, and have shown that PrE maintains its pluripotent state by controlling the expression levels of SOX17, GATA6, and FOXA, which are influenced by the presence of BMP signaling.

One major computational result is the development of a robust and feature-rich ecosystem for solving differential equations in Julia (J. of Open Research Software, 5(1), 2017). The work allows easy and robust application of computational tools in solving differential equations in biological and physical models. This result  has been highly cited (>750 times) since its publication.

 

Broad Impacts

The results gained from this project have shed new light onto fundamental principles governing early mammalian embryo development. The new knowledge gained on how mouse embryo organizes itself to generate normal blastocysts will lead to an improved understanding of early human embryo development and its defects. The new tools developed to model interplays among cells, biochemical signaling, gene regulation, and continuum mechanics at the single cell level will be applicable to many other complex biological systems. The computational tools to infer dynamic transitions of cells from static omics datasets, and the robust Julia package for solving differential equations have been widely used and highly cited already, showing strong impact.

The project has provided many research and training activities for trainees at all levels, and significantly increased participation and engagement of students at the interface between mathematics and biology. Personnel trained on the project include five postdoctoral fellows (2 females), six PhD graduate students (3 females and 3 of them obtained PhD in mathematics), two undergraduate students, and five high school students (3 females; 1 female student awarded the 2020 Regeneron Science Talent Search semifinalist).

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2022
Modified by: Qing Nie
